=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of what’s going on and how you might approach playing this game:

1. Game Type and Genre:
 • It’s a grid‐based puzzle game with elements of block pushing similar in spirit to classic “Sokoban” puzzles.
 • The focus is on moving objects around the level while managing transformation rules, meaning every move can change the state of certain objects.

2. Mechanics:
 • You control an avatar that moves on a grid.
 • The level is set up with walls (impassable), floors, and special tiles like “hole” and “ground.”
 • There are two key box types: “box” and “boxin.” A “box” pushed onto a “hole” transforms into “boxin” (and you gain a little score). But if a “boxin” then goes onto “ground,” it turns back into a “box” (and you lose a bit of score).
 • Other interactions include bouncing (for example, when a moving passive item labeled “bbox” hits the avatar) and an odd undo mechanic when these “bbox” objects collide with walls in a certain way.
 • Collisions with walls make your avatar step back, so you have to plan your moves carefully.

3. Objective:
 • The win condition is met by eliminating all “box” sprites from the level – the game ends (and you win) when the sprite counter for boxes reaches zero.
 • In other words, you want to remove boxes from play by using the transformation interaction (by pushing them into holes).

4. Win/Loss Conditions:
 • Win: You clear all the boxes.
 • Loss isn’t explicitly mentioned here, but making the wrong moves (such as accidentally turning a “boxin” back into a “box” or triggering unwanted undo moves) could force you into an unsolvable position.

5. Overall Strategy:
 • Carefully plan your moves. Since boxes can change state depending on where they are (hole versus ground), you must precisely control where you push them.
 • The basic goal is to push each box onto a hole so it transforms into a “boxin” (gaining a little score) and eventually clear them from the board. However, be cautious: if a “boxin” moves onto a ground tile unexpectedly, it reverts back to a “box” (and you lose some progress/score).
 • Work from the outer edges of the level inward (or vice versa) in a thoughtful sequence so that you don’t block yourself or accidentally trigger the undo mechanic with bounce effects.
 • Utilize the environment – use walls and the layout to help reposition boxes without unwanted bounces.
 • Think a few moves ahead: every push might have a ripple effect (especially with interactions like the “bbox wall bbox” undo action), so planning and spatial awareness are key.

In summary, you’re solving a spatial puzzle where your timing and move order determine whether you ultimately clear all the boxes by carefully directing them into holes. Good planning and anticipation of chain reactions in tile behavior will win the day!

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_LEFT
2: ACTION_RIGHT
3: ACTION_DOWN
4: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
